articles.content:
An axiom is a statement that identifies the base of knowledge and of any
further statement pertaining to that knowledge, a statement necessarily
contained in all others, whether any particular speaker chooses to identify it
or not.  An axiom is a proposition that defeats its opponents by the fact that
they have to accept it and use it in the process of any attempt to deny it.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 155

articles.content:
Existence exists—and the act of grasping that statement implies two corollary
axioms: that something exists which one perceives and that one exists
possessing consciousness, consciousness being the faculty of perceiving that
which exists.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 124

articles.content: “You cannot prove that you exist or that you’re conscious,” they chatter, blanking out the fact that proof presupposes existence, consciousness and a complex chain of knowledge: the existence of something to know, of a consciousness able to know it, and of a knowledge that has learned to distinguish between such concepts as the proved and the unproved.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 154
